loc: Kinta District (near  Kampung Kepayang), Negeri Perak
rmk:
With advancing age I find that hearing the calls of some of these species with high pitched notes is difficult for me, the Crimson Sunbird included. I had good observations of this male and was even able to do some videos of the bird preening and calling, using a wall as a support for the long lens (see video here: https://youtu.be/nqNipRcCS2c). Wells (2007) notes that the song/calls are undescribed in the review area of his book (at the time of publication) but I am sure many local bird watchers have heard and recorded the song/calls since. A recording of some songs and calls of the bird I observed can be found here. The song is described by Cheke, Mann and Allen 2001, in their comprehensive account on Sunbirds, as a “chirping trill or a loud sharp trill, often uttered on the wing”. The sonogram of the song shows that it is a high frequency sound and the upper limit is above the audible range of hearing (> 20 000 Hz). I observed that the song often comprised three notes, repeated frequently (occasionally 2 notes). One type of call made was a high frequency note, single and uttered infrequently, here while preening.
Reference: 
1.	Robert A Cheke, Clive F Mann, Richard Allen (2001). Sunbirds: A Guide to the Sunbirds, Flowerpeckers, Spiderhunters and Sugarbirds of the World. Helm Identification Guides
2.	Wells, D.R. (2007). The birds of the Thai-Malay Peninsula: Vol. 2 (Passarines). Christopher Helm, London.

loc: Siberut Selatan, Kabupaten Kepulauan Mentawai, Sumatera Barat
rmk: Unseen bird singing from canopy, best guess is a sunbird. A rapid, slightly harsh, high-pitched warble. James Eaton suggested either Crimson or Van Hasselt's sunbirds. Listening to recordings from nearby areas (Singapore and Sumatra), this recording matches quite closely some examples of Crimson, assuming that those are identified correctly.
